text: the 99 women I want to start by saying
what an absolute honor it has been
talking with you on these various
subject on women's life and where they
stand in the world today but I have to
admit that there is one subject that
really kind of got to me and today we
were asked what message we would send to
our granddaughters and even if I don't
have a granddaughter who I don't even
have a daughter yet for that matter a
lot of things came to my mind but the
first thing that popped up in my head
was my own grandmother and she was born
in the Canary Islands in 1936 she was
the youngest sibling by far and she
could really thank her existence to the
fact that her parents they needed
someone to take care of them in their
old age but my grandmother was and still
is a very assertive woman and she had
dreams of her own and she wanted to go
to the UK to study medicine but back
then in order to leave the country for a
woman of only 19 years you had to get
your parents to sign your papers so
filled with hopes and dreams my
grandmother went to her father and asked
him to sign her papers but instead of
the warm yes that she had been expecting
she received a slap for her insolence
what needed a daughter of his self for
further education she had everything she
needed back home and if everything else
failed she could just get married my
grandmother was a very strong young
woman but she was absolutely devastated
after this and she felt as if her dream
was being torn from her hands by none
other than her own father but one her
mother my great-grandmother saw her
daughter's plight she did something
probably for the first time and to
everyone's surprise she went against her
husband's wishes and without his
knowledge signed the papers my
grandmother she wasted no time she sold
some of her clothes and jewelry and she
fled to London and here she started
studying to become a nurse and he'll
tell you It was as if a whole new world
had opened up to her and she started
living life to the fullest and then as
it tends to happen she fell in love she
fell in love with an Icelandic man
my grandfather and to make a long story
short they got married had children and
moved to Iceland now the question posed
here today made me think of her because
after giving it a thought myself I think
the first message that I would send to
my unborn granddaughter is the same
thing that my grandmother has told me my
entire life
yet an education it doesn't matter what
you do after that just get an education
and she didn't just throw it out there
because it sounded good
my grandmother had first-hand experience
of just how education can prove itself
to be an invaluable key to independence
but sadly not all women are so lucky as
to have education at their fingertips
it's a shocking 2/3 of those who can
neither read nor write are women not to
mention the strong link between lack of
education and poverty women make up 70%
of all those living in absolute poverty
and you know I have to admit you this
all seems very strange and alien to me
in a way I mean the benefits of
educating women are countless educated
women have fewer but healthier children
they're able to contribute their talents
to the market thereby increasing the
country's economic growth and you know
there's also strong correlation between
a country's gender gap and its
international competitiveness simply
because the nation's competitiveness in
the long run depends significantly on
whether and how it utilizes half of its
resources women so why aren't we
educating our women now I believe that
the answer may lie in the second message
that I would give it to my granddaughter
the fight for gender equality or women's
rights it's not a struggle against the
distinct oppressor
it is against the deeply held set of
beliefs and assumptions that we women
far too often hold ourselves you see
although it is true that women's rights
have come a long way from just gaining
the right to vote to more women than
ever graduating from universities
societies deeply integrated belief that
women are inferior
still leads to millions of girls being
neglected murdered or reported each year
it is my belief that the 20th century
was really the time when we were
fighting for civil and political rights
for women and what lies ahead of us in
the 21st century is a struggle for
social and cultural rights of women
changing the way we think about women in
general to stop knowingly and
unknowingly questioning a person's
abilities based on their gender
according to the global gender gap
reporters published today
Iceland my home country is now for the
fifth consecutive year number one in
closing with the world's gender gap and
believe me when I say this this is the
fact that Iceland does take immense
pride in and I can't really describe the
feeling when I saw the news earlier here
today and it is true we have come a long
way but we also realize but there's
still a long way to go for example women
still have a 10 percent unexplainable
lower income than men they only make up
21% of corporate boards and a shocking
third of Icelandic women has been
subjected to violence we know but even
if we have come a long way we have to
keep fighting because if we force
ourselves to feel content with the
situation as it is just because we sit
on top of these lists then we'll never
reach full equality and the truth is
that the struggle that lies ahead of us
is a much less tangible and therefore a
more elusive struggle
it requires introspection and awareness
awareness of the injustice that takes
place all over the world and of course
the courage of speaking up when we see
it and thankfully there are many women
in this world who are willing to speak
up even in the face of grave danger and
on October 7th the BBC ran the first
international interview with a 16 year
old worldwide role model Melina Malala
yousufzai sari an absolutely incredible
girl who even after being shot by her
adversaries continues to speak up for
women's
right to education it's women like
Malala that I want to tell my
granddaughter about so here's the third
and final message to her know the
history of women's rights don't be
overly grateful for having rights that's
exactly what they are but do be grateful
to the women who fought for those rights
and show them the respect of staying
aware and speaking up so that their
fight won't be in vain or become
stagnant and ladies I sincerely hope
that you all feel as inspired as I do
after the day's event and I feel
incredibly honored to be marking the
finish of this amazing series by the BBC
and a big THANK YOU to the BBC for its
remarkable contribution to women's
rights I have to admit to you I have no
idea what the world is going to be like
when my granddaughter is born but I can
tell you this that after today I'm
feeling a lot more positive and although
it may seem impossible at times to
change these outdated beliefs that stand
in the way of women's education and
gender equality as a whole our world is
ruled by little else than thoughts and
ideas and therefore it is in our power
to change it and only through the power
of awareness and the courage of standing
up can we move forward to an equal and
just society thank you
